attributes.description:

There are those among us who are fortunate enough to work in the games industry, and then there are those who go on to do it for so long that they achieve legendary status. Andy McNamara, EIC of Game Informer for 29 years, is one such legend. Well, so much for that old pile of rocks - Andy announced that he’s stepping down from his post to move onto the next thing. We wish him a fond farewell on this week’s edition of the Weekend Roundup, but we’ve also got all these other stories to get through! attributes.title: More Exclusives Coming To Xbox!
attributes.description:
Sign up for HBO Max at  https://bit.ly/hbomaxroundup

It’s the weekend, and you know what that means! It’s time for another exciting round up of the biggest gaming news stories in the industry. Microsoft has been buying up all sorts of studios to work on exclusive titles and it sounds like they plan to acquire even more developers going forward. This news comes just after Microsoft confirmed the date for their Xbox Studios showcase coming July 23rd. While that’s all very exciting, it’s time to stop and really think about how much game executives are getting paid. Of course, Bobby Kotick’s salary has been under fire before, but now the CtW Investment Group is asking EA’s shareholders to vote against letting the publisher have total say in executive compensation. In a surprising twist, Capcom actually acknowledged that a majority of their sales are digital, which leaves us wondering about what the rest of the industry looks like. Lastly, and potentially the most exciting story for gamers everywhere: there’s a group at Valve who would like to make a full length Half-Life game and even bring it to consoles. Of course, what would a Weekend Roundup be without a 5-Second Review? This week Brian finds himself in an affair with Catherine: Full Body.

attributes.title: Did Xbox lie about CROSS-GEN?
attributes.description:
The Xbox Summer Showcase finally happened, but there have been some CROSSED wires when it comes to CROSS-gen (haha, a joke). Leading up to the Xbox first-party showcase, Xbox boss Phil Spencer blogged that all Xbox Exclusives would be cross-gen for the next couple of years. However, games that were announced for the Xbox exclusively during the showcase have not been listed as being available on the Xbox One. OOoooooo SCANDAL! If lies weren’t bad enough, some concerning reports say we are about to start experiencing the impact of Covid-19 in the games industry. At least it’s not all doom and gloom this weekend because it looks like we’ve got 4K 60fps mode coming alongside the release of Spider-Man: Miles Morales - also, Metacritic is finally deciding to do something about those pesky review bombers. And lastly, this week's Roundup wouldn’t be complete without a 5-Second Review of Paper Mario: The Origami King. Have a good one!

attributes.title: PlayStation Showcase Scandal
attributes.description:
It’s become common for everyone to dump on the latest and greatest digital event showcasing games this summer. Everyone constantly seems disappointed, and PlayStation’s August State of Play was no different - but this time there’s actually something worthy of a good rage. One of the games shown, Aeon Must Die!, brought attention to a major scandal between the games developer (Limestone Games) and their publisher (Focus Home Interactive). Don’t worry, it’s not all bad news! We’re also rounding up other highlights from the State of Play that don’t include theft and villainy. Well... Nintendo DID announce Pikmin 3 Deluxe and then immediately the original Pikmin 3 down from the eshop... so maybe this is a downer episode. We have got a new Dr. Disrespect sighting and it looks like he’s gonna be on YouTube for a while...maybe?? Who even knows anymore. Lastly, we're talking about why Apple has refused cloud gaming services to exist on the app store. Of course there’s a 5-Second Review of Carrion and THAT’S NOT ALL! Rocksteady Studios finally announced Suicide Squad. Anyways, Brian’s still on vacation but hopefully this substantially packed edition of the Weekend Roundup will keep you satiated while we all wait for his return.

attributes.title: Xbox Says They Don't "Need Exclusives"
attributes.description:
Visit http://att.com/5G for more information on AT&T 5G!

attributes.title: CD Projekt Red & GoG cave to Devotion backlash
attributes.description:
Go to http://expressvpn.com/roundup to get an extra 3 months of ExpressVPN for FREE!

Cyberpunk 2077 wasn’t the only game to be removed from a storefront this week. Good Old Games, a subsidiary wholly owned by CD Projekt Red, recently pulled down a game called Devotion from their online store.

This was the Chinese made game that was previously featured in headlines before because it featured a Winnie the Pooh meme of the Chinese President, Xi Jinping and that caused a primarily chinese audience to review bomb the game in efforts to get it delisted.

Also as a result, the Chinese publisher of the game, Indievent, lost its business licence from the Chinese Government, supposedly due to the incident. The current assumption is that GoG or CDPR faced pressure from either an angry fanbase  or the Chinese government and removed the game from GoG.com.

If true, it’s a terrible look for CDPR who obviously has their own issues and for GoG who previously has had a reputation for being rebellious and gamer friendly. Saving face to save some sales when it comes to an artistic medium feels particularly scummy.

In addition to our headlining story today - were also covering Assassin’s Creed Valhalla’s experience boosters, Among Us coming to Switch, an Interview with Nintendo’s Doug Bowser, and Henry Cavil hurt his leg while filming season two of The Witcher.

attributes.title: Every 5-Second Review in 2020
attributes.description:
Thanks to ExpressVPN for sponsoring our channel http://expressvpn.com/inside

It’s been an action-packed year of video game news and new releases - and we have covered it all right here on the Inside Gaming Roundup... but there is one part of the show that gets the least time to shine. 

That’s not because it isn’t a good part of the show but because by it’s very nature it excels at being the shortest part of the show. So today we are dedicating an entire episode to every 5-Second Review shot in 2020.

It’s going to be a supercut for the ages as Brian passes judgment on all of your favorite and least favorite games from 2020 in this 5-Second Review Roundup. Let’s go.

* Note and fun fact: The last 5-Second Review of the year isn’t in here because the Roundup published on 12/19/20 is the last video we shot and edited in 2020. It was done the very last day we were in the office… So okay, yeah, yeah, the title of this video should be “Every 5-Second Review from 2020 (except the last one)” but no one wants to read all that. Besides if you miss it that much you can go back and watch that episode of the Roundup again! Anyways, thanks to everyone for watching, commenting, and making the roundup so much fun to do every week.
